Hey, Garrett, I wish I could come and support you in court but living in Australia makes it a bit hard. But I will send an email. Now I have been through what you are going through when I was a young bloke I was a keen motorbike racer. We lived in a city called Melbourne which at the time and still expanding so these race tracks which were on the outskirts of town or out of town when they were built were now part of the suburban sprawl as they called it. and it was creating some problems. So the governing body who already had a property with a motocross track and a dirt track on a big property with plenty of room about 70 kilometers from Melbourne. So we all got together the racing clubs and raised a lot of money and the governing body borrowed some money and before you new it the little town of Broadford had it's own motorcycle racing complex. Beautiful all problems solved one would think. So a year or so goes by big meetings big attendances loans are being paid ahead of time local businesses are going better than they have in years everything is going great. Until the property owner next door with his 500 acres or so did a deal with a developer and subdivided his property. So now instead of having one neighbor we now had 10 neighbors. and these neighbors the last thing they wanted to hear was the sound of race-tuned motorbikes ringing their necks all day. I could never understand to me it was like music but to them it was noise. So they got together and tried to shut us down. for the next two years or so we had to fight with everything we had to save that motorbike track. We had raffles we had fundraisers to pay the voulchers I meam lawyers Haha. And we won and that track is still there to this day and still operating. What saved us, in the end, is we had the business community behind us because from day one we had an agreement with the business community that where ever possible we would buy all our products locally. I don't know how this little story will help you because your circumstances are a bit different but I just wanted you to know I totally understand what you are going through. And want to say don't ever give up because you never know. And one more this is one of my favorite channels we can't loose you.  All the best Garry

In response to recent events, I oppose the rezoning of land adjacent to the Bradenton Motorsports Park. Historically, when residential units are placed adjacent to locations with high aggregate noise, those places end up facing uphill battles with their community and county. New proposed residents will eventually complain to local leaders about noise, that they agreed to when purchasing their domicile. Those leaders will begin to pressure that track owners and make it harder to obtain the necessary licenses to operate each year. Eventually those things lead to the collapse of the tracks. Those same tracks that bring thousands of people into the area annually for multiple events. Those tourists who spend their money in that county. Stay in your local hotels, buy your local foods, buy fuel, buy merchandise. All that gets taxed in Manatee County. You know what people who live there do? Go on vacation to some other county or state. Your only interest here is the potential property tax revenue you can gain, while dismissing the current revenue you already have. And you are heading into potentially one of the worst times to pursue the housing market, while potentially destroying a 50 year old track. After you lose that track, where is that revenue going to go? All those people who race there, where are they going to go‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.right onto your roadways. So while you may gain a few dollars for some property tax, you‚Äôll lose out on a sprawling community who come here because that track and the people who run it, make it somewhere that people want to be. There‚Äôs plenty of space elsewhere in Manatee County, destroying a part of history and a small piece of tourism just to sell some land.

@cleetus2mcfarland20 you did a good job outlining the issue, and helping us understand what is going on.  However, you didn't do a good job articulating your point (that they shouldn't rezone to allow this development) to the board.  You really needed to help them understand what is at stake (which you did partially), what the real world ramifications to this zoning issue is (actual decibel levels of the noise, proximity and safety zones), how what the developer's proposal is detrimental to their potential clients (people buying the homes and how they are putting them in harms way), and why what they are doing will be detrimental to the community (through the eventual removal of your business which I think you did well).  One other point you needed to address was taxes.  The community stands to make a lot of money though property taxes by allowing the creation of 4000 homes... "The median property tax in Manatee County, Florida is $1,973 per year for a home worth the median value of $214,000. Manatee County collects, on average, 0.92% of a property's assessed fair market value as property tax."  Average build prices are closer to $350,000 or $400,000 to build (averaged nationally).   You're looking at roughly $13,300,000 in potential tax revenue you'll need to fight.  You need to bring in professionals on your side to fight this; a land use & development Attorney,  an Architect, and possibly specialized Engineers (Acoustics & Civil) to draft a report and have a real solid foundation on which to base your fight.  Good luck brother!  ----> As a second option; crowdsource the purchase of all of the adjacent homes, turn them into vacation rentals for people coming to the track for events or racing.  Thus allowing you a buffer between the traditional home owners and the track.

A racetrack that was near my old home was built in 1948.  It had weekend stock car racing and not had major complaints until the early 80‚Äôs.  Thats when a nearby neighborhood group got together and filed a petition to have the track shut down because of the noise factor.  There were several hearings held and even though the track owner tried to work with the petitioners and become noise compliant by adding mufflers to the race cars the petitioners would not budge on their goal of shutting the racetrack completely down.  So, the track owner was left with no choice but to pull a power move and explain that the petitioners nor the city had the power to shut the track down due to it having been ‚Äúgrandfathered‚Äù into the zoning laws that were instituted decades before. The Indianapolis Speedrome racing facility still operates to this day and I‚Äôm guessing a lot of those in the complaining neighborhood group have moved or died out of this world by now!  The track does require mufflers on the cars to curb the noise level but the racing continues. I would rather keep it as agricultural land. Food over furniture is a better way of thinking. If you have a county boundary and you overpopulate that county, it shows irrespective county management.   This is what is called "Over - Integration" (an unforseen overlapping of boundaries).  This type of development is why some lone villages get swallowed and integrated as part of neighbouring towns, thus losing independence. And that, in turn, is how small towns grow into big cities. We have these boundaries in the UK, known as county boundaries.  Without boundaries, there will be no significance between villages, towns, and cities, hence why there are boundaries in place to prevent over - integration.  Buildings "Outside" These boundaries are placed so that any pollution (be it Air or Noise) is not within effective reach of domestic households or places expecting a large population gathering day by day.  These facilities have the same rights as the industries and domestic shops in villages or towns that they are situated or attached to.  In this application, it suits the appeasement of the residents.  Building residential buildings next to established land or on agricultural land stated as agricultural use would be unsuitable for residence and is therefore deemed "unconstitutional"  I rest my CASE.  (I am in no circumstance legally trained, nor hold a degree or doctorate to support the information that I gave stated. I am a normal man with a normal education background)  Peace Garrett.  I hope that the racetracks and the land around it, stay as they are and were intended to be.  "A Racing Facility with Significant History, surrounded by agriculture and beautiful scenery".

Show some, yourself... or be assumed to be a mouth-breather who doesn't even care enough about the issue to wash his hair and put on a collared shirt. Try that next time.  And, if you do get a next time, you should probably mention that: In the *Manatee County, Florida Code of Ordinances, Chapter 2-21 - Miscellaneous Provisions and Offenses, Article II - Noise, Sec. 2-21-33 - Exemptions* ... "(10) *Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. * , the emission of sound or noise from lawful and proper activities on school grounds *and places primarily used for* athletic contests and *sporting events* " applies to your business, because it is primarily used for sporting events. Now what you really ought (need?) to do is to attempt to get the specific language of "motorized vehicle racing" added to that list of exemptions. Why? Because, the way the language currently is, there is a non-zero chance that a good lawyer, armed with a petition signed by ~80% of the homeowners in that future neighborhood, could convince the council that the exemption was intended to be for events such as football games, baseball games, track & field events, and the like - where the only real noise is that of a cheering crowd - but NOT automobile/etc. racing, where a cheering crowd of spectators would not even be heard above the noise of the engines. However, if you can get the language modified to include motor(ized) vehicle racing, specifically, then you would *absolutely* be safe from such an argument, because you can simply point out that the activity is specifically mentioned as an exemption. Yeah... You might even want to buy a suit for that conversation, instead of merely a shirt that has a collar. . . .

Read:  Appeals Court Affirms that Race Track Was Not a Nuisance Jun 14, 2013  An Ohio state appeals court has affirmed the ruling of a trial court that the noise emanating from a race park did not constitute a ‚Äúnuisance.‚Äù   The plaintiffs in the case were residents of Sterling Township, who lived in close proximity to the Moler Raceway Park. The park was situated on 40 acres of land in Sterling Township on which a quarter-mile dirt track motor raceway is operated.   Notably, there are no zoning regulations or noise ordinances in the township. Nevertheless, the raceway is surrounded by trees in order to help with noise and dust. As adjoining landowners, the residents sued Moler on June 16, 2008, alleging that the operation of the raceway constitutes a nuisance. The residents sought damages for loss of use and enjoyment of property and diminution of property values. They also sought injunctive relief including, but not limited to, a complete shutdown of commercial activities at the raceway.   On May 3, 2010, a four-day bench trial began. Proffered testimony revealed that the raceway is in operation approximately 25 days per year, holding racing events primarily on Friday evenings, and occasionally on Saturdays and Sundays. Each racing event consists of roughly 100 cars per night racing in four separate classes on a dirt track, which is wetted down before the races begin. Each car that participates in a race must have a muffler. The raceway opens around 4:30 p.m. with racing beginning at 7:00 p.m. and lasting typically until 12:30 a.m., although some race nights have extended until 1:45 a.m. During this time period, the residents claim that the noise produced by the Raceway is loud enough to interfere with conversations held inside or outside their respective houses and disrupts their ability to sleep. Furthermore, several of the Residents contend that ‚Äúpost-race activity,‚Äù including honking car horns, can be heard as late as 3:30 a.m.   In addition to the testimony of the residents and other persons living around the Raceway, expert witnesses testified on behalf of both parties. The residents‚Äô expert witness, Eric Zwerling, is a noise expert who testified that noise from the Raceway was an ‚Äúunnatural‚Äù sound with decibels (dBA) reaching levels that interfere with a person‚Äôs sleep. The defendants‚Äô expert witness countered that the sound from the raceway is no greater than sounds emanating from other local events.   On June 28, 2010, the trial court issued a decision denying the residents‚Äô request for a permanent injunction to halt operations at the raceway. Nevertheless, the trial court also determined that the raceway could become a nuisance and, consequently, ordered several restrictions on further operation of the raceway. These restrictions provided that all races must be completed by midnight and that racing may only be held on Fridays. Moler appealed the 2010 Decision and, on September 6, 2011, this court remanded the case to the trial court ‚Äúto determine with clarity whether or not a nuisance exists or is anticipated to exist, what type it is, and what restrictions are proper pursuant to Civ.R. 65(D).‚Äù Brackett v. Moler Raceway Park, LLC, 195 Ohio App. 3d 372, 2011 Ohio 4469, ¬∂ 27, 960 N.E.2d 484 (12th Dist.) (Brackett I).   On remand, the trial court issued a decision similar to the 2010 Decision with the exception that the restrictions placed on the Raceway were deleted and the following language was added:   ‚ÄúThe court finds that the operation of the defendants‚Äô race track is not a nuisance per se.   THE COURT FINDS that acts constituting a nuisance has [sic] not been proven by clear and convincing evidence.   There are no sound or noise standard [sic] in Sterling Township, Brown County, Ohio.   An anticipated nuisance can be enjoyed by a Court, but only when the factor [sic] show that the anticipated or threatened nuisance will occur by clear and convincing evidence. This was not done in this case.   The plaintiffs have failed their burden of proof. The Plaintiff‚Äôs case was not proven by the required standard of proof.   The plaintiffs case is hereby dismiss [sic].‚Äù     On appeal, the residents‚Äô made four assignments of error.   In their first assignment of error, the residents made several arguments regarding the expert witnesses in this case. First, the Residents contend the trial court erred in considering Moler‚Äôs witness, because he had not performed any independent noise testing in the Sterling Township community, had not performed a study or published any articles relating to the impact of noise, and did not state his opinions to any probability or reasonable scientific certainty. Second, the residents argued the trial court erred in stating that the testimony of Zwerling and their expert was ‚Äúconflicting.‚Äù Finally, the residents asserted the trial court erred in stating that the noise testing by Zwerling was performed on only one day and was, therefore, a ‚Äúsnapshot‚Äù test.   The appeals court was unmoved. ‚ÄúWhile we do not deny that the parties presented convergent views of the noise level coming from the raceway and its impact on the surrounding Sterling Township community, it is apparent that the trial court found Moler‚Äôs evidence, including the testimony of the defendants‚Äô expert, to be more credible. After a careful review of the record, we are not persuaded by the residents‚Äô contention that the trial court‚Äôs judgment that the testimony of Zwerling and the defendants‚Äô expert is conflicting is against the manifest weight of the evidence. Although the residents clearly find their expert to be more qualified in the field of noise testing, the trial court was in the best position to observe the witnesses and ultimately make credibility determinations. See Schneble, 2012 Ohio 3130 at ¬∂ 69. Accordingly, the trial court did not clearly lose its way and create a manifest miscarriage of justice in making such credibility determinations.‚Äù   In their second assignment of error, the residents argued that ‚Äúthe trial court erred in stating that the residents had the burden of proving their case by clear and convincing evidence when the proper standard in a nuisance case is proof by a preponderance of the evidence.‚Äù   The court agreed with the plaintiffs on ‚Äúthe proper standard in a nuisance case.   ‚ÄúHowever, the residents sought a permanent injunction against Moler to completely shut down all commercial activity at the Raceway. In order to obtain injunctive relief, the residents had the burden to prove their allegations by clear and convincing evidence. Brackett I at ¬∂ 16; City of Youngstown v. McDonough, 7th Dist. No. 00 C.A. 19, 2000 Ohio 2628, 2000 WL 1847662, *2 (Dec. 12, 2000). Thus, even though the Residents were only required to prove the existence of a nuisance by a preponderance of the evidence, they were further required to establish the need for injunctive relief by clear and convincing evidence.‚Äù   In their third assignment of error, the residents argued that, ‚Äúrather than following the directive of this court in Brackett I to provide further analysis of its decision, the trial court simply deleted the restrictions it had initially placed on the Raceway. In doing so, the Residents contend the trial court ‚Äòcompletely and totally‚Äô failed to follow this court‚Äôs order and, consequently, the trial court‚Äôs 2012 decision was made in error.‚Äù   The appeals court disagreed, writing that ‚Äúbased upon our review of Brackett I, as well as the trial court‚Äôs 2010 and 2012 Decisions, we find that the trial court did not err as a matter of law by not following this court‚Äôs directive. The trial court did as it was instructed on remand. As such, the residents‚Äô third assignment of error is overruled.‚Äù   In their final assignment of error, the residents argued the trial court ‚Äúerred in conducting independent research prior to ruling on the case.‚Äù   The appeals court countered that the trial court ‚Äútook judicial notice of facts regarding State Route 32 and the Franklin County metropolitan area. The statements do not indicate that the trial court relied on outside research in forming its opinion. Rather, the trial court‚Äôs statements regarding State Route 32 and Franklin County are introductory material regarding the geographical areas in and around Sterling Township.‚Äù   The panel concluded that ‚Äúif any of these statements were made in error, the error would be harmless, as the statements made by the trial court are not relevant to the trial court‚Äôs findings and, as analyzed above, sufficient, competent, credible evidence exists on the record from which the court could conclude that the Raceway did not constitute a nuisance. Schneble v. Stark, 2012 Ohio 3130 at ¬∂ 16.‚Äù   Corinne Brackett, et al., v. Moler Raceway Park, et al.; Ct. App. Ohio, 12th App. Dist., CASE NO. CA2012-06-009; 2013 Ohio 1102; 2013 Ohio App. LEXIS 990; 3/25/13   Attorneys of Record: (for plaintiffs-appellants) John H. Schaeffer, J. Douglas Drushal, Patrick E. Noser, Critchfield, Critchfield & Johnston, Ltd., Wooster, Ohio. (for defendants-appellees) Joseph L. Trauth, Jr., Michael T. Cappel, Keating Muething & Klekamp PLL, Cincinnati, Ohio.

Here's the email I sent, hopefully we can make a difference!  I am writing to express my opposition to the PA-21-09/Ordinance - Large Scale Comprehensive Plan Map and Text Amendment 23-11 PLN2111-0048 to rezone land near the race track to residential. This plan presents many potential issues for the race track and I do not believe it is in the best interests of the citizens.   The track is an important part of the community and is a major source of entertainment and tourism for the area of Manatee County. The natural noise of the races will undoubtedly bring complaints from new residents, and I believe this will be an ongoing source of contention and stress. Additionally, this plan will have an economic impact, as the track is a vital part of the local economy.   I understand the need for housing in the area, but this is not the right location for it. I urge you to consider other alternatives that will better serve the community and its residents.   Thank you for your consideration.

I agree 100% with what you are saying Cleter. I have seen it up here in Northern Indiana. In Winona Lake, IN, the 4H fair grounds used to host huge races all the way up to the early 90s. Houses started going up and someone sued the Fair Grounds because of the noise. The homeowner ultimately won and the race track shut down.  A few years ago, the Fair Board attempted to restart racing. Everyone was excited to bring it back because the person who got racing shut down had passed away and left the estate to the family. The Mayor of the adjoining town (Warsaw), several small business owners, and people who lived around the lake where the Fair ground is at all went in and put a ton of money down to force a stay on the lawsuit from the 90s and shut the restart down. The Fair board literally had all the support from a lot of people in the community, but all the people who put the money in to force the stay, won and the fair board wasn't asking for much other than having races once or twice a month to make some money for 4H programs and to bring in new things to keep the Fair Grounds from closing. Such a bummer and I will do my part to help out.

The classic blows in, blows off and blows out scenario. The developer buys some ground, pays to get the rules changed, harvests the profit, moves on and leaves the local government to pick up the pieces. This has a familiar ring to it, often involving the closure of airports. In some instances, a developer's long game is to get the airport land, develop it and harvest even more profit.

Cleetus, couldnt find an email for you, but heres what I sent:  I OPPOSE   Application PA-21-09/Ordinance - Large Scale Comprehensive Plan Map and Text Amendment 23-11 PLN2111-0048    for the following reasons:   1) on behalf of the nearby racetracks, I oppose this development due to the well known issues following urban development near such establishments, which has led to the demise of many formerly successful tracks around the country;   2) on behalf of the future residents of this development, I oppose the development and sale of properties which will almost certainly be unsatisfactory and which the new residents may not be able to reasonably enjoy, due to the pre-existing associated noise, fumes, and lights from the raceways, which the suggested amelioration methods will likely not sufficiently attenuate;   2a) on behalf of the residents who will have to deal with the considerable traffic, noise, and disturbance surges which happen around events at the nearby raceway establishments;   3) on behalf of the local inhabitants, state and county, which currently derive considerable revenue from the guests attending events held at the racetracks, ranging from taxes upon sales and income to the promotion of the area around the globe through event broadcasts and participation via the Internet, making Manatee County a desirable destination for motorsport enthusiasts domestic and foreign;   3a) again on behalf of the local citizens, who may well suffer deprivation of essential services as their government will undoubtedly be spending an unprecedented amount of their tax dollars upon lawsuits from parties adversely affected by a decision to allow this unwise development, which is ultimately the responsibility of this county government;   3b) again on behalf of the local racetracks and other businesses which would be adversely affected by the loss of the tracks, such as hotels, mechanics, fuel establishments, tire shops, sign, paint and body shops, restaurants, rental car establishments, food trucks and other vendors;   3c) on behalf of the employees of the county and state, who will bear the brunt of the inevitable and constant noise and odor complaints, likely requiring increased manpower and much paperwork;   4) on behalf of all who take tremendous joy in having access, be it remote or immediate, to the incomparable excitement, noise, smell, and incredibly beneficial social stimulation that defines motorsports.   Thank you so much for your time and attention,    ...and signed it.

Look up Mesa Marin Raceway. This SAME EXACT thing happened to Mesa Marin. Opened in 1977, Mesa Marin was part of NASCAR racing Series and critical to the formation of the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series. The city refused to renew the tracks conditional use permit, in 2005, following noise complaints from people living around the racetrack in housing built after the racetrack was built. Thus ending nearly 30 years of racing and varied events at Mesa Marin.

While I can't help oppose this as I'm in the UK, not the USA and my email would not hold any weight, this situation has happened multiple times. Lots of race tracks across the country (Oulton Park, Mallory Park, Donington Park, Brands Hatch, Cadwell, Croft and Knockhill) are hampered by restrictive noise limits that came into force after new residents complained about a racetrack that they moved next to. These aren't even drag strips playing host to massive V8's with no mufflers and short pipes, they're full blown race tracks playing host to motorbikes and cars as well. This has had the knock-on effect of all of these tracks struggling to make ends meet in the long run as the noise restrictions prevent them from running every single day, they have to be careful about what events they run. It even affects the national racing series, British Super Bikes (BSB) in that at certain tracks, they teams have to run a different exhaust system to make the bikes quieter.  The most egregious example of this is Donington Park. They have super strict noise restrictons on the 'quiet' days (So much so that bone stock Ducacti's sometimes get flagged up by the noise monitoring) yet the circuit is under the flight path for East Midlands Airport.
And off my message goes. I've included in it a message about how residential development has practically killed my local area, turning it into an opioid epicenter. And I know there is an argument for Laguna Seca since development hasn't killed that track off (yet), but they've got bigger sponsors and host events for large racing organizations. I wish y'all the best of luck. Since I live in Ohio, I cannot be there, but at least they'll get my message.

These kinds of "Zoning" changes are never good for the existing property owners, only the developers that want to rezone and build. Perfect example: My family moved to Tucker, Ga. from Decatur, Ga. in 1971. I was 13. The property is now mine as my parents are now deceased. The back yard was at the time adjacent to many hundreds of acres of woods. A developer came in and wanted the whole thing rezoned and to build hundreds if not thousands of "low income" apartments on the land. Never mind the traffic nightmare THAT would have caused! OR the impact of "less than stellar" inhabitants! The same ones that drove us out of Decatur in the first place!  I remember having to sit through late night "Planning Committee" meetings with my parents (and others) for months until the zoning was changed to "Industrial". There is now a HUGE Industrial Park there and the traffic from THAT is bad enough! Although it WAS nice when I got a job with a company there and had a five-minute-commute! I shudder to think what would have happened if those apartments had been built. We very likely would have had to move out of a just finished home! In fact, thinking about it now, I am one of the (very) few, if not the only ONE in the three adjacent neighborhoods that has lived here all this time! just spitballing some reasons to oppose   if housing is put adjacent to the race tracks they'll probably close.     if they close people are gonna race on the streets   if they close you lose travel, fuel, service, lodging, logistics, etc commerce/jobs   if they close the urban sprawl will just leapfrog or accelerate.     People might actually move to these new houses because they're near tracks and then they would relocate.   Being able to race year-round here draws in extra money in the winter, but also obviously attracts content creators/investors (boosted boiz, you, etc), which then attract more reasons to come to Bradenton.   "Florida man" is a brand and the race tracks are safe (legal) spaces for Florida Men  If the new housing demand is high build them next to a quiet golf course, that's where Florida houses are supposed to be built.  We don't build new houses next to airports for a reason, zoning obviously needs to consider "loudness".  We can't move the racetracks to the industrial parks or the airport.  4000 homes is ~10,000 more people needing access to Lake Manatee.  Is that infrastructure in place, can the ecosystem handle that? Saying shutting down race tracks is woke or leftist or something, that might play well with some.  If you can't get around this zoning thing, maybe there's some kind of informed consent or something buyers/HOAs would have to agree to and that is you live next to a racetrack with loud cars and your complaints will not be heard.. you signed up for this.  And then maybe a compromise on hours the high noise is allowed.  There are lots of reasons to fight urban sprawl, and a lot of the arguments are already prewritten.  Google some key terms "urban sprawl pros cons" and "fighting urban sprawl."  Or look up how others were successful in preventing it.  Good luck, Cleet.

We stopped a subdivision based on the effect of water run off next to an airfield (which would eventually kill us off).  When rain falls on farmland the foliage slows the run off water down.  When rain falls on roofs, roads, foot paths, driveways, etc and then into drains the run off is much faster (no foliage to slow it down)  and this can cause flash flooding downstream in the run off zone on other properties.  I don't know the lay of the land but this may be food for thought.

Garret I have just compiled and sent and email to the commissioners, and blind copied you on it, feel free to use any of the information I have included in your defense of your properties. Also do not be afraid to ring up the governor as he's a western PA guy who appreciates his freedom as well!       Good Luck Brother!  "I am a property owner¬†of two large plots myself in a rural area of Pennsylvania, approximately 35 miles northeast of Pittsburgh. We are in a rural area with active farms and are feeling the incursion of housing developments. I fully understand what is at stake here as I have personally seen several farms get closed down for noise after dark, smells from manure from the barns, and being spread on fields by folks who move in either unaware or somehow thinking they are the only opinion that counts because they bought a house in an area they never researched.¬†  We also have a local dirt circle track race park in our area as well. Lernerville Speedway. I have lived here 34 years, and the track has been here every one of them, and at least 20 years prior to that. I live over 6.5 miles west and upwind of the track, and on some summer weekend nights, the cars sound like they're doing donuts in my field behind the house... Remember I'm 6.5 miles UP WIND, meaning it is even harder for sound to travel my way since the prevailing winds are pushing the sound back towards the track over very hilly western Pennsylvania terrain with hardwood trees well in excess of 25 feet height, (averaging 60+) between my property and the track. It still comes in loud and clear. See the google terrain map below.  Across the street, literally, from the track is a housing development, circled in red. Nobody there really likes the track, and every so many years, there's a big blow up about how the track should do this or that about the noise, but once again, since the track was there LONG before they were and thanks to our very conservative base in the Butler County area, they have respectfully, and rightfully pushed back, "You knew what was here before you purchased." There have been hurt feelings and property values have taken a hit as some wanted out and had trouble finding buyers that were more astute than the original¬†buyers on the initial¬†purchase.¬†   Having said the above, I truly believe, with all due respect to your positions of office, you would be negligent to your community taxpayers, present and future, developers, and investors to allow such a neighborhood development¬†with all its headaches to go forward in good conscience. If allowed to move forward, you are setting trap for repetitive and costly litigation, potential vandalism, and general ill will in your community. I would highly recommend keeping the zoning in that area as agricultural, and leaving the property, that the center of,¬† is less than a mile from existing racing facilities¬†as a buffer zone. That is one sixth the distance I am from a track, which means it will be 36 times louder than I experience, a thought I honestly cannot comprehend.¬†  That is not an imaginary number. Sound, like light, generally propagates following the inverse-squared rule. When the sound moves out in all directions (as do all natural sounds), the energy must cover more area the farther it expands. The relationship is that, if the sound doubles its distance, it is 1/4 (1 over 2 squared) as powerful. At 3 times the distance, it is 1/9 as powerful. (The same energy is in the entire pressure wave, it just spreads farther, so you only hear the part that hits your ear.) The inverse of this as you get closer, is just multiplication. 6 times 6, or 36 times as much sound energy only being an average of less than 1 mile from the existing facilities. For the homes that would be at the property boundary, the sound intensity only gets worse, 72 times more for a half mile, and a quarter mile would be a staggering 144 times louder. A 25 foot tall earthen wall even with dense foliage will barely reduce this sound spectrum.¬†  I would urge you to very strongly consider the above, and DO NOT grant the zoning change for the benefit of all parties involved. I stand no monetary benefit from your decision, other than the lack of entertainment those racetracks provide to me on a regular basis.¬†  Thank you for your time and consideration in this matter.¬†"  Kevin K...

Man, this sucks... I've unfortunately been up against developers as an abutter multiple times fighting these planning boards, and in my experience, they'll vote in favor of the development that lines their pockets the most, which is almost always going to be the subdivision. In one, the developer actually went and filed a false wetlands survey to get an additional 50% of his property listed as buildable so he could cram another 6 lots into the cul-de-sac, I actually caught him, we had another survey ordered and they still approved his subdivision, even though it had like 20 violation. In the other, in order for his subdivision to work, he needed my driveway, which was a deeded easement and the only way onto his property, they legally took my driveway away, gave it to the subdivision as a road then moved my driveway to the cul-de-sac road and then gave me a new driveway on the cul-de-sac, and state law allows the planning board to do this as long as they feel you're getting something equal or better in return, and if it's for the good of the neighborhood, town, city and state, which translates to "we get to collect another $200k in property tax each year, and you get a new driveway and address, and your home is more desirable now because it's in a cul-de-sac". Money grubbing losers.

To give it your best shot you need to get real world numbers into the council document and the application. Measure the DBA on the border of your property during a race weekend.   Establish current noise level documented and be accepted by the developer and council in writing in the application, Included in the development with the comparison to an airport and concert. Establish current use how often the track is used have that level of usage documented and be accepted by the developer and council in writing in the application. 50 weekends and an additional 200 week days a year at current usage.   occurred  Basically you need to establish existing use and hours, document this and have the Council and Developer agree to the current use scenario's that are contrary to the development. If you use a lawyer you can establish that that existing use will be unaffected and the mitigation of this existing use falls fully with the Council and Developer.    It would be worth a lawyer writing this up and sending to the council and developers with a written response required, you can then go to the meeting and advise this has all been documented and is known to the council and developers based on the letters you send or serve, whatever you need to do to document their receipt of the letter maybe even film hand delivering them.  I suspect documenting all the existing use, noise and time into the system and mitigation being fully the Council and Developer would be the only way to have a foundation to argue in the future when council change the way you can operate. Sadly without it you can be pushed out as you indicate but with this documented the Council may have to assist as they are paying you to reduce or alter hours of operation as mitigation and that has a price.  I would suggest both raceways do this as individual applications as that would make the council deal with hours and days of use individually meaning every day and weekend could be an operational day and most hours could be the same. Light pollution and noise would be documented and accepted and mitigation to existing use is per property and per system.  The above aproack delayed the closure of a 4wd park we operated for 20 years and when the Council finally closed us down they paid for the development of a new park for us, new parking facilities, new buildings and new courses as these were all documented existing use. Good Luck.

I used to live just off campus at UNC Charlotte. For those of you unfamiliar with the area, it is about 4 miles from Charlotte Motor Speedway. There are lots of hills, valleys, and trees in that four miles and yes I could hear the Coca Cola 600 every May. This exact thing killed Shuffletown Drag Strip in Charlotte. They built that strip in 1958 in the middle of nowhere. Eventually a developer converted farmland to housing developments and the people who bought houses there killed it over noise that existed long before many of the new homeowners were even born. Shuffletown closed it's gates for the last time in 1991 and today's generation of hot rodders have no idea what was lost. Today the former dragstrip is a park.  Charlotte Motor Speedway has enough political muscle to fend off attacks like this. Small tracks like the Freedom Factory do not.

47 years ago  in Prince Georges county Maryland this same thing happened . Beltsville Speedway a newly constructed 1/2 asphalt speedway was built and very popular, also NASCAR sanctioned. Within 6 years it was all over. Everything was fine for the first 3 years. Builders bought land about 1/4 mile away for  a townhome project a year later. They knew of the racetrack going in before even buying the land. Within a year as homeowners began moving in they started complaining about the noise of the racetrack. They complained to local government, councilmen and the Prince Georges county gov't. 1 year later after local complaints the race track was mandated to run mufflers on all classes of cars. Another year go's by and the races track had another  restriction placed on it. This time a 16 foot wall had to be built if it wanted to continue having races there so a wall was built to appease the county and nearby residents. Again complaints were lodged against the racetrack in the off season so the track owner just threw his hands up and said " I'm done."  If they approve the request to approve building next to your race track so fine but the developer is paying for the wall and homeowners will be notified  before signing home contract they aware of the racetrack and they still want to purchase the home in that development. This is exactly what happened to KCIR in Kansas City. The track had been open and operating since the 1960s, and developers built giant McMansions within a mile radius of the track, and the new, wealthy owners complained about noise. City eventually threatened to condemn the land, and proposed turning it into a park.   Long story short, the track closed and the city discovered that the cost of mitigating leaded fuel contamination in the soil was too high, so it still sits 11 years later. We still don't have a drag strip within the KC Metro; you have to drive to Topeka to drag race legally.

"To whom it may concern,  Thank you for allowing comments on this matter.  As a patron of the Bradenton Motorsports Park in Manatee County, I feel it is imperative to reach out regarding upcoming changes to the area.    Motorsports are an integral part of American and Floridian culture and are under siege in many states.  Many times, the sport is threatened without malicious intent, and those who may doom the sport may not know they are doing so.  That is the case today.  This type of development change has historically impacted motorsports and caused the closure of facilities simply because of unexpected noise.  While not wishing to offend, race cars do produce more noise than normal cars.  This is why race tracks like those at Bradenton Motorsports Park are built with buffer zones such as agricultural areas between them and residential areas.  It was a deliberate choice to build the tracks where they are to avoid any disturbance to the residents in Manatee County while also providing cultural enrichment to the area as well as a large economic draw to the area.    By allowing residential construction so close to the race tracks, the community is inviting complaints for noise which will strangle the operation of the race tracks.  We have seen this happen many times across the country, just recently in Atlanta this very thing happened.  The complaints in turn lead to noise regulations that cripple the tracks ability to conduct races, and without the ability to host races or events the track closes and another part of American history and culture dies, to say nothing of the economic loss of fans and competitors from across the country coming to participate in this wonderful pastime.  As a resident of Minnesota, my household has visited and patronized the tracks in Manatee County despite the distance, as have hundreds of thousands of fans across the country.  Your county has a very unique and vibrant culture that we as Americans would be poorer for losing.    It is for this reason that I feel compelled to reach out and urge you to oppose the upcoming map changes in order to protect this amazing resource you have and ensure it can remain for generations to come.  Respectfully,"

oops I got carried away with my email:  I would like to go on-record to specifically state that racetracks are a vital part of local and sometimes even state economies. I myself have spent hundreds, sometimes thousands of dollars to visit racetracks across the country. This money spent is only as a tourist and a spectator -- someone who simply watches a race occur. What I should also mention is that I've also spent well over two thousand dollars multiple times per year to race in my own car on a real racetrack with real rules and regulations. All of this money goes straight back into local and regional economies; whether it's supporting the workers at the track, surrounding businesses, or the track itself, all of that money eventually goes back into the local economy.   Besides the economic argument, there is also the case to be made about safety. Yes it's true: having access to a regulated and sanctioned race track keeps racers off the street. I know this as a fact through first-hand experience. While I do not myself condone nor participate in street races, I know of many examples where my peers participate in those exact activities because of the lack of access to places to do it where it should be done -- on a track. While I do not have factual statistics to give you relating to this, my first-hand experience tells me that availability of real race tracks keeps people from street racing, has kept many of my friends from street racing. These same friends have participated in races with me on the same track after finding out that it was possible to do so.  Lastly, on a personal note: Motorsports are a dying breed. While it'll probably still last at the professional level for many years to come, maintaining these openly accessible venues is a step in the right direction keeping one of America's greatest and most original pastimes alive. It is for this reason that I ask you, on a personal level, to keep this track open and available and avoid zoning residential areas anywhere nearby that will, inevitably, cause the track to shut down.

Reminds me of large airports.  They're built away from homes and other habitats along with the area around them classified as non-residential space.  Then people take it to the government to reclassify the area to allow residential on those areas.  If that didn't work, they took it to court to allow it.  Several years later, usually after the original builders sold their property,  the new owners sued  the airports due to the noise, and won. That's why aircraft now have noise abatement procedures they have to follow immediately after takeoff.  A lot of smaller airports just shutdown. The same happened to a lot of racetracks around the country.

They did this to our local drag strip over a decade ago. First they said it wouldn't affect the strip at all but after they built the homes and everyone moved in, the people started complaining about the noise. Then the homeowners all got together and sued. Now there is a noise ordinance in place that requires mufflers on all cars participating at the drag strip and they severely limited the times in which drag racing can take place. It effectively killed drag racing in our area. The new noise ordinance requires the noise level to be at or below 85db over an 8 hour period at the track property boundary. That makes it impossible for anything but street cars to compete there.

I deal with land development throughout Florida for several large investment groups and I'll give you the short take on how Manatee County is going to do this.  The only question that will matter in the end.....Do the race tracks bring in or generate as much 'reoccurring' annual revenue for the county that the residential development will?  The short answer is, no, not even close.  History, tradition, and all the other points you made about the tracks are irrelevant to these people. This is all about the money this new development can bring to the county and all the pet projects the County Commissioners can fund with that windfall.  Manatee is not unique, almost all Florida cities and counties operate the same way.  Unless you can find some sort of legal hole in this development (Ex. endangered species or state protected wetlands impacts) that you and your attorneys can exploit and file suit over, the planning board will likely approve this application.  Once they do, the County Commissioners will then very likely approve it using the planning board as cover.  And you're right, once it makes its way out of Manatee County, Tallahassee will simply rubber stamp it.  I wish you the absolute best of luck with this because you're also 100% right in that a development of that size will likely kill both race tracks over time.

This is what killed Englishtown. Legendary strip in NJ. Basically nowhere else to go anywhere close now.  I get wanting expansion for more homes, but more homes also brings more traffic. Even if the race tracks weren‚Äôt a thing, those 4500 homes will bring in MUCH more vehicle traffic. This harms everyone as it increases travel times, expands emergency services coverage, increases road traffic in the area which also decreases the life of the roadways, and increases accident risk. What Bradenton SHOULD be doing if they wish to add more housing, is instead take that space and add just a little bit to it if multistory town homes or apartments. This will limit the amount of space needed while adding room for a few thousand residents as well. Not only that, but it will keep them still plenty far away from the racetrack, and it doesn‚Äôt bind anyone down into a mortgage to a home near a racetrack. If the people renting there don‚Äôt like it, they can leave after their lease is up no problem. It also encourages bringing in more younger people vs older. Younger people stimulate the economy of a town better than older people. They are also much more likely to be ok with hearing the race track a little bit. Bottom line is the racetracks drum up tons of business for the town, and it will only improve. Whereas the housing will also do that as people move in, however it will be trading agricultural zoning and keeping a cornerstone location of the town (the racetracks), for more suburban housing that really isn‚Äôt even necessary. There is PLENTY of farmland near the tracks. When I lived and raced at Boyd's Speedway years ago. They started developing the area around the track. The track has been there since the 50's. The track was there first and the developer wanted to shut the track down. Luckily the track is still open a running.
Bill Elliott (yes the NASCAR champion) and I defeated a proposal of a similar development with a similar density per acre using what we felt was effective because our argument addressed an issue that's seldom explored. Our argument was that the tax revenue from the development would be far below the amount of the development's financial demands in services and material expenses. We calculated the density, the number of people per acre, their ages and arrived at the average cost per acre or housing unit.  Examples included the annual cost per child to educate them in the local schools, fire,  emergency medical, and police services to name a few (based in part on the ages of adults -- young, middle-aged, or senior citizens). I suspect that when you calculate the burden of the development on tax revenues against the taxes paid, you will find a deficit that runs into the millions. Make sure the board knows that, while the developers make their money and move on, the citizens of Manatee Co. will pay millions per year, every year, until the development is torn down in maybe 50 years. From there you can easily use the argument of tax dollars and stimulus to the local economy by the tracks helping to relieve the local tax burden and build the economy. This argument is especially effective when the developers are seeking to change the property's classification to another classification as they are here. In our experience, when the zoning is changed, the development tends to get denser, standards decline and costs to the county increases.   Despite what we are told, not all growth is good growth and not all growth brings money into the county coffers. Some growth in residential areas is profitable to the developers who grab their profits and leave us with an ongoing deficit that lasts for generations.

A 25" solid fence will not make the race cars inaudible at nearby houses. Correct acoustical design by professionals in environmental acoustics would be able to put exact numbers on the situation using computer modelling. There is no guesswork involved. I know this because I did this type of acoustical design work for over 20 years. I do not know the local rules for these developments, but this type of problem happens all the time in Australia. Urban sprawl results in homes being built next to industries that have existed for many decades and usually it results in massive cost of noise control for the existing industry or it shuts down the activity. Money from new housing development is a powerful incentive for local government officials to approve the development.

I sent the following email  Manatee Board of County Commissioners,  I Oppose Application PA-21-09/Ordinance - Large Scale Comprehensive Plan Map and Text Amendment 23-11 PLN2111-0048.  I specifically oppose the application for the following reasons:  1. Rezoning property as residential, next to already established racetracks, will result in the future implementation of ordinances and/or regulations that will create a burden upon the racetrack, and will substantially hinder the business operations of the racetracks (e.g. Noise ordinances, public disturbance regulations, etc.).  This will make it impossible for the racetracks to continue operating, and thus going out of business.  2. These are not ordinary racetracks.  These racetracks are watched and supported by millions of fans around the world, on a daily and weekly basis.  3.  The owners of the racetracks are positive role models for the community and people around the world.  They spend a significant amount of time teaching and educating about the industry.  They also provide opportunities for people to get involved.  4.  The racetracks and the events hosted at them, attract thousands and thousands of people to the area, multiple times per year.  This brings massive revenue and funding to the local community and local businesses in the area.  5.  Enough land is already being stripped and developed throughout this country.  Our agriculture is being flattened for development, pushing out wildlife, and killing the local ecosystem even further.  This application would not only be an attack on the land, but also on a business and industry that millions of people are invested in.  6.  This is a choice between 4,000 houses or preserving agriculture and a business that is supported by millions of people.  The choice is easy. Stop Application PA-21-09/Ordinance.  Thanks for your time and I truly hope the Manatee County Board of Commissioners makes the right choice in this matter.  Best Regards, Personal Info Omitted

Having served on a Town Board previously, you are fighting against the property tax revenue that building homes is going to generate, so you've kinda already lost, and it doesn't matter how many petitions you are able to generate in opposition, the words of the 'against' petitioners won't speak louder than the dollars 'for'. The guaranteed win strategy is to buy the property in question. I can also tell you that non-residents opinions mean nothing to the board. You are 100 percent correct that being professional and having a positive attitude in front of the board is also critical. Noone should go in there with the mindset that the board is their enemy and try to be combative, that is a no win strategy. Get hard facts and evidence on how much tax revenue the racetracks generate and present that data to the board, but if it doesn't outweigh the property tax developing houses will bring, not to mention the tax revenue other town operated services like water, sewer, gas, garbage, fire dept., recreation district, library district...  Fight a good fight brother, get legal council to look at other creative legal options too (petition to re-zone the property, etc...). The real battle isn't at the board meeting, its actually before the meeting happens in documents provided to the Mayor/Board/ and staff before hand. The board is supposed to have an open mind in quasi-judicial matters brought before them, but I can tell you usually minds are already made up by meeting time. Try to get personal meetings with staff, the mayor and the board members prior to the meeting, that will have way more impact than any passionate words said at the board meeting.

What tends to happen is that racetracks bring in revenue for businesses around them and in turn create popular spots that attract people. When developers see that people are interested in the area, they start looking for property that they can develop and get top dollar. They don‚Äôt care about why or what made the area popular, or what happens to the area after they sell off their properties. They‚Äôre only concerned with how much money they can make and the rest is everyone else‚Äôs concern. In a perfect situation, the people who enjoy the reasons that the area is popular would be the ones to purchase homes in the area. However, that‚Äôs nearly never the case. The developers push the houses to the market and sell them as fast as they can to whoever wants ‚Äúa house‚Äù. Then you end up with angry neighbors who don‚Äôt care about the attractions that made the area thrive which in turn shuts down the attractions and makes the area less desirable for businesses and lowers property values basically turning the area into a run down town that businesses move away from.
